citation.article-title: A new genus of marine budding phototrophic bacteria, Rhodobium gen. nov., which includes Rhodobium orientis sp. nov. and Rhodobium marinum comb. nov.

p.s: Rhodobium (Rho.do'bi.um. Gr. n. rhodos, rose; Gr. n. bios, life; M.L. n. Rhodobium, red life)
Cells are ovoid to rod shaped, 0.7 to 0.9 μm wide, and 1.0 to 3.2 μm long.
Motile by means of polar or randomly distributed flagella.
Cells multiply by budding and asymmetric cell division.
Phototrophically grown cells contain intracytoplasmic membranes of the lamellar type together with bacteriochlorophyll a and carotenoids belonging to the spirilloxanthin series.
Facultative photoheterotrophs that grow anaerobically in the light or aerobically in the dark.
Photosynthetic cultures are pink to red, while aerobic chemotrophic cultures are colorless.
Optimal growth occurs at 25 to 35°C, at pH 6.9 to 7.5, and in the presence of 1 to 5% NaCl.
Photoorganotrophy with simple organic compounds as carbon sources is the preferred mode of growth.
Ubiquinone 10 and menaquinone 10 are the major quinones.
The G+C contents of the DNAs range from 61.5 to 65.7 mol%.
The phylogenetic position is in the alpha-2 subclass of the Proteobacteria.
The type species is Rhodobium orientis.
